datafield.subfield: 00004 The key idea of our approach is that non-Abelian lattice gauge theories can emerge from Abelian theories, provided adequate hoppings of atoms in an optical lattice are imposed. For example, the two-point basis associated with the 2D crystal structure in (a) can be assigned with the two-component {\it particles} (let us call them {\it dimers}) of the non-Abelian $\mathrm{U(2)}$ gauge theory. It turns out that the spatial separation of the {\it dimers} is irrelevant, and therefore the components can be chosen arbitrary even on a simple Bravais lattice (b) if hoppings of {\it dimers} are described by unitary matrices. To ensure the unitarity we have to engineer adequate tunnelings of atoms (c)-(d). The latter can be more easily realized experimentally if the {\it dimers} are oriented perpendicularly with respect to the Bravais lattice (e).

00000 The key idea of our approach is that non-Abelian lattice gauge theories can emerge from Abelian theories, provided adequate hoppings of atoms in an optical lattice are imposed. For example, the two-point basis associated with the 2D crystal structure in (a) can be assigned with the two-component {\it particles} (let us call them {\it dimers}) of the non-Abelian $\mathrm{U(2)}$ gauge theory. It turns out that the spatial separation of the {\it dimers} is irrelevant, and therefore the components can be chosen arbitrary even on a simple Bravais lattice (b) if hoppings of {\it dimers} are described by unitary matrices. To ensure the unitarity we have to engineer adequate tunnelings of atoms (c)-(d). The latter can be more easily realized experimentally if the {\it dimers} are oriented perpendicularly with respect to the Bravais lattice (e).

For example, the two-point basis associated with the 2D crystal structure in (a) can be assigned with the two-component {\it particles} (let us call them {\it dimers}) of the non-Abelian $\mathrm{U(2)}$ gauge theory. 00009 Energy spectrum $E(\phi_x)$ as a function of the Abelian magnetic flux $\phi_x$ for $\alpha=\beta=\pi/3$ and the mass parameter $m_{\rm eff}=0$ (top panel) and $m_{\rm eff}=3$ (bottom panel). When the mass of the components is introduced and increases, the reflection symmetry of the spectrum is broken and the spectrum widens and eventually grows apart.

00010 Energy spectrum $E(\phi_x)$ as a function of the Abelian magnetic flux $\phi_x$ for $\alpha=\beta=\pi/3$ and the mass parameter $m_{\rm eff}=0$ (top panel) and $m_{\rm eff}=3$ (bottom panel). When the mass of the components is introduced and increases, the reflection symmetry of the spectrum is broken and the spectrum widens and eventually grows apart.
00012 Square unit plaquette of a $\mathrm{U(N)}$ lattice with the constant Wilson loop.
00011 Transverse Hall conductivity $\sigma_{xy}$ (in units of $1/h$) as a function of the Fermi energy for $\alpha=\beta=\pi/3$, $m_{\rm eff}=2$ and $\phi_x=2/5$.

00005 The procedure of engineering of the optical lattice potential which allows for realization of a non-Abelian SU(2) gauge theory. First, we superpose two orthogonal standing waves along $\hat{x}\pm\hat{z}$ directions (a), which give rise to the checkerboard potential (c). The two standing waves can be independently shaken by introducing periodic modulations of the phases of the superimposed waves. Then, we add an extra standing wave along the $z$ direction (b), which breaks the separability of the potential along the $\hat{x}\pm\hat{z}$ directions and changes the potential to the square anisotropic lattice (d). Controlling the shaking parameters allows us to control tunneling amplitudes of atoms which are indicated in (d). Finally, an additional standing wave along the $y$ direction and a trapping potential $V_{trap}(z)$ are added. The latter selects out the pairs of lattice sites that leads to creation of the crystal structure with the 2D squared Bravais lattice and the two-point basis as in Fig.~\ref{dimers}( e).

00006 The procedure of engineering of the optical lattice potential which allows for realization of a non-Abelian SU(2) gauge theory. First, we superpose two orthogonal standing waves along $\hat{x}\pm\hat{z}$ directions (a), which give rise to the checkerboard potential (c). The two standing waves can be independently shaken by introducing periodic modulations of the phases of the superimposed waves. Then, we add an extra standing wave along the $z$ direction (b), which breaks the separability of the potential along the $\hat{x}\pm\hat{z}$ directions and changes the potential to the square anisotropic lattice (d). Controlling the shaking parameters allows us to control tunneling amplitudes of atoms which are indicated in (d). Finally, an additional standing wave along the $y$ direction and a trapping potential $V_{trap}(z)$ are added. The latter selects out the pairs of lattice sites that leads to creation of the crystal structure with the 2D squared Bravais lattice and the two-point basis as in Fig.~\ref{dimers}( e).

00008 The procedure of engineering of the optical lattice potential which allows for realization of a non-Abelian SU(2) gauge theory. First, we superpose two orthogonal standing waves along $\hat{x}\pm\hat{z}$ directions (a), which give rise to the checkerboard potential (c). The two standing waves can be independently shaken by introducing periodic modulations of the phases of the superimposed waves. Then, we add an extra standing wave along the $z$ direction (b), which breaks the separability of the potential along the $\hat{x}\pm\hat{z}$ directions and changes the potential to the square anisotropic lattice (d). Controlling the shaking parameters allows us to control tunneling amplitudes of atoms which are indicated in (d). Finally, an additional standing wave along the $y$ direction and a trapping potential $V_{trap}(z)$ are added. The latter selects out the pairs of lattice sites that leads to creation of the crystal structure with the 2D squared Bravais lattice and the two-point basis as in Fig.~\ref{dimers}( e).
Simulation of non-Abelian lattice gauge theories with a single component atomic gas

We show that non-Abelian lattice gauge theories can be simulated with a single component ultra-cold atomic gas in an optical lattice potential. An optical lattice can be viewed as a Bravais lattice with a $N$-point basis. Atom located at different points of the basis can be considered as a {\it particle} in different internal states. Appropriate engineering of tunneling amplitudes of atoms in an optical lattice allows one to realize U$(N)$ gauge potentials and control a mass of {\it particles} that experience such non-Abelian gauge fields. We provide and analyze a concrete example of an optical lattice configuration that allows for simulation of a SU(2) gauge model with an adjustable mass of {\it particles}. In particular, we observe that the non-zero mass creates large conductive gaps in the energy spectrum, which could be imporant in the experimental detection of the transerse Hall conducitivity.
